headline: Christmas fan mail special on 'The Five'
subHeadline: Juan Williams, Katie Pavlich, Jesse Watters, Dana Perino and Greg Gutfeld celebrate Christmas by answering fan mail questions.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams, co-host
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone, I'm Juan Williams, along with Katie Pavlich, Jessie Watters, Dana Perino, and Gregory Greg Gutfeld is here. It's 5 o'clock in New York City and this is "The Five." Merry Christmas, everyone. We're so excited to have you join us for our fun-filled Christmas special. We're answering your Yuletide questions. They come from social media, and we'll be doing it for the full hour. So grab your eggnog, and let's go. Question A, it's a Facebook question from Peggy S. -- what is the weirdest Christmas gift you ever received? Katie Pavlich.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Like back in the day? They're like little round cardboard things that kids would play with and you just trade -- they're like baseball cards almost. And I just never was like into them. So I got them. I don't know. That's weird.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: But it wasn't for a girl; it was for a boy.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: But clearly it didn't work for you.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters, co-host
utterances.utterance: I just want to wish you a Merry Christmas, Juan.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I had a great morning unwrapping gifts. It was just really beautiful to celebrate with everybody. So everybody out there, Merry Christmas.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld, co-host
utterances.utterance: Was this at a La Quinta Inn?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I got coal in my stocking.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: My kids think it's a funny prank, and I don't think it's that funny. But it happens.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: It didn't come from your parents; it came from the kids?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: It might've come from both. I blacked it out.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I'm a bit naughty, Juan. Very naughty.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: So it's not a weird gift. It was a valid gift.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I think it's a season of forgiveness. You know, we should -- I mean, we've got to celebrate.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: You don't know what I've done, Juan.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Well, I want to celebrate with you. It's Christmas.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Well, the weirdest gift I ever got was a gift I got last year that I can't tell you what it was. It was from my dad. And I'm not allowed to have one of these.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I think I know what it is.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I'm not saying what it was.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Can you just say what it is?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying it was weird. No, because I don't want anyone --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I don't want the NYPD to come to my department.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Yes. Okay, we know what it is.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Okay. That was a weird gift.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Shocking; it will give you that.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Apparently he was watching a lot of Fox News coverage [unintelligible] "crimes getting really bad in New York." Drops that in the mail. I'm not even sure you can mail that, but -- did he mail it?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That's a felony, across state lines.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: But you don't know what it is.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: My wife once said to me after she had been sort of carjacked that she wanted --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: So anyway, she wanted a pink one and the people at the NRA and everybody else said they were going to give it to her. But you didn't have -- what color was it?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean [unintelligible] I'm not telling you what I got. I'm not telling you -- let it remain a mystery. If I could mention one thing about that. A girlfriend of mine in April of this year -- this is five months after our Christmas show last year, her dad went into a hospital. I said -- I called, I said "I hope your dad's feeling better." And she said, "well, he has one question for you." She said "for five months, he's been wondering what was it that your dad got you for Christmas?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: And I'm like, "so it's still a mystery. It's still the weirdest gift I ever got." But it was out of love.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: It came from a place of love.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: All right, Gregory, the weirdest Christmas gift --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I'm trying to think because like, I get like -- the obvious one was that unicorn jumpsuit --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- that was given to me on The Five Christmas show like four years ago, which inflated, and it was -- you could look it up, it's somewhere. Or just drop it in. But I -- you know what I was thinking -- the album "I Robot" by Alan Parsons Project.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I have no idea what that means.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You don't know Al? It's a whole album -- it's the guy who produced Dark Side of the Moon. It's a great -- but my sister gives it to me. I never heard of this guy and then I ended up listening to the album every day for like a year. But it was all about robots.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Oh. Is that the one where if you sync it up to the Dorothy --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That's Dark Side of the Moon.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Because if you sync it up to The Wizard of Oz, you -- it all [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: But you've got to smoke something really strong for it to work.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: By the way, Jesse, you have a special place in this show.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Because the weirdest Christmas gift I ever got was that snowflake suit.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Why aren't you wearing it? It's Christmas.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Well, because you know how liberals are. We're snowflakes.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I liked it so much, even though it was a weird gift, that I wore it at home for my family on Christmas Day last year.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Well, yes. I think I wore it through dinner. I don't know about the whole [unintelligible]; I don't know if I went out afterwards.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: All right. The second question for our Christmas special, this one comes from Lindsey C. -- it says, "What's the most annoying Christmas song?" I'm going to go first on this one. The Chipmunks. You know, "oh, Alvin." I'm like, "wow." Yeah, Greg?

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: You told me I don't know any other Spanish songs, and I do.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: And I said only Ricky Martin. But that is the most annoying Spanish song, in my opinion.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I'm going to have to agree with Jesse.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: And I'll tell you why. I'm going to agree with you.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I love that song. I love it.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Feliz Navidad. Years ago, Peter and I invited my sister to Washington, D.C. for Christmas. And as a surprise, we brought her to New York for her first time.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: And at one point, we got on the subway to go from point A to point B, and there was a guy on the subway who had a terrible voice and he was singing Feliz Navidad over and over and over again for money. And we got stuck in the subway.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: And he just kept playing it over and over again. So anytime I hear it now, it's not like the wonderful version; all I can imagine hearing is that guy's really bad [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I think that he was just --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Just giving it a shot. Yeah. And I -- I think that you're right.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: He just didn't deserve a lot of money.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Which is one of the great words in the language.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes. I will say every single Christmas song there is, every single one is annoying and it's annoying because they aren't --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Good enough songs to be played year-round. They're like -- they're like the turkey. You only have turkey once a year because it's a mediocre bird. Both of these Christmas songs have mediocre melodies, are incredibly annoying. And so we have -- we're forced to listen to them from the end of November to the end of December. They make me sick to my stomach. I'm sorry, America, but you asked the question. They're the worst songs on Earth. And if God wanted to, he'd agree with me.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: If God wanted, he may agree with you. I don't know. But wait, so, let me take you into your deep Grinch-most mode and ask you then what is your favorite Christmas hymn?

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: He doesn't have one. None of them.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Anarchy in the U.K. by the Sex Pistols.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I don't even know what to say. I don't know what to say. Anyway, did you -- what was it?

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I somewhat agree with Greg, but only post -- or pre-Thanksgiving. So any Christmas song that is played before Thanksgiving.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: And after New Year's. So there is a period of time. It's the day after Thanksgiving through December 25th. And then it's just stop.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: It's like wearing white after Labor Day. You just can't do it. No, you can do that, but you can't [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Only if you're in the alt-right.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: But here's the reality. Right now, on November 1st, they start playing Christmas songs.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: But they're ruining it. It's like extending it way too long.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: You take the value and the fun out of it.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Christmas should only be once every four years the way they used to do with the Olympics. Then we'd appreciate it more. We'd save more money. We'd be able to afford mortgages and college. But instead, every year we spend all this money giving each other gifts that we don't even like.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: All right. Question number three, from you. It comes from Kent B. It says what's everyone's favorite Christmas memory? I'm going to go to somebody who comes from the land of snow and ranches. Dana Perino.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Well, actually, my favorite memory was from being up in Newcastle, Wyoming, with all my family gathered. My father and -- had two brothers and cousins and we were all there together. And there was one year where it snowed so badly that we really couldn't go anywhere, and we ended up playing cards the whole weekend. But we also -- we had those old wooden long sleds.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: And my grandfather would put us all in back of the pickup, and we would go up to the top, and then one uncle and my dad -- my dad and then my uncles would be on there with the rest of the kids to put some weight, and we would fly down these gullies, and my grandfather would drive down, pick us up so we didn't have to walk back up the hill over and over again. Then we'd come back to the house and say, you know, to my grandmother, "Mama put on the hot chocolate." And --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: So it wasn't a gift. It was just being up there.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I think that's a gift. That was wonderful. Greg.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Well, no, I mean -- never mind.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You know, I grew up in Northern California, and I think it only snowed once in my entire life there. So we went to Skyline Boulevard and people had a -- nobody had sleds because it was Northern California.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: So we're Skyline, which is above CSM College in San Mateo, and we're like sliding on the lids of garbage can.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: And we went to a donut shop and had donuts.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And then I killed a drifter.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: So your favorite Christmas was a white Christmas.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: My favorite Christmas was this Christmas.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: It has been such a great Christmas. I had so much fun this morning with the Yule and the tide and the trees. It's just been beautiful. Feliz Navidad.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: What was the weather like today?

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Oh, I grew up in the snowy part of Arizona. So I think my favorite Christmas memory is where my dad would hook up sleds to the back of the pickup truck.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: We live out, like, in the middle of nowhere.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Yeah, don't try this at home. But we did, and I survived.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: They wouldn't plow the road, so he would just drag us in the back of the truck through the roads. And it was so much fun.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: We would do that. And there was another time where he came home with a puppy, and that was pretty good.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And my mom would always make amazing Christmas rolls, so those were always really good.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Wait. I saw your face when you said puppy. It was like, "Urgh.”

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Well, that's the best thing you can get at Christmas time.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I thought you were saying maybe you had some reservations.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: You can also get a car with the big red bow on top. That beats a puppy any day.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You know, what's great? If you drive the car with the bow, and the gift is the bow. "Oh, look at the bow I got you.” "I'll take it off my car that I got for myself."

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: But if you got a Peloton, that would be great.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You want to bring up controversy? Well, by the way, so mine is kind of sentimental. I remember once, you know, my dad wasn't there, and we didn't have much money. And my brother went out like on Christmas Eve. He said, "Come with me." And we went and we got the last Christmas tree on the Christmas tree lot, and we were dragging it home. Later in my life, I always think it reminded me of like, you know, peanuts or something.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: All right. One last question. This one is an Instagram question, and it comes from Loretta Fogate [spelled phonetically] at Fogate.35. What's your favorite Christmas movie?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Who wants to start? Oh, wait.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I don't think so. I think it's --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: But I do think it's a Christmas movie. [LAUGHS]

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I saw Home Alone the other day, and, man, that movie is good.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: And then I saw Home Alone Two, and it's underrated.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: People think Home Alone Two is not that good. It stands up there.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: By the way, why were you watching?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: You know, Netflix has a lot of stuff --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- and Disney +. And, you know, it keeps going after you finished one movie.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: It's a Wonderful Life. A classic.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It's good. The book is good --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: One of the worst movies ever made.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: And now we're going to start a Christmas dinner fight between Dana and Greg.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Dana started the big debate, which is, is Die Hard Christmas movie?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: It is -- but it is a Christmas movie, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: There are people who would disagree.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I mean, I would say it is.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Oh, the movie does take place on Christmas. Yes.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: But is -- I don't know. I there are some people who say it is not. I'm not one of them. So I don't know.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: By the way, the other day I was watching a cable and up came Miracle on 34th Street, which I think is a pretty good movie.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I think that is a good one, too.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You know what? It got like two stars.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: You haven't seen Die Hard. Get out of here.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: All right. We're just getting started. Stay right there, The Five's Christmas special returns with more funny questions straight ahead. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Well, welcome back to our Christmas special. We're going to answer more of your questions. I got some good ones here. All right, Greg, I'm going to start with you.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: This is from Joanel C. [spelled phonetically] from Facebook. Would you rather live where it only snows or the temperature never falls below 100 degrees?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: These are weird questions because I don't believe in the prison of two ideas, Dana.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Oh, you have an unbending mind.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: But to say that you can either have this or have this, that's not how the world works. There's an infinite --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Is it a fun question really?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I would definitely go with heat over cold because I could always have a nice swimming pool built. You could always cool down with air conditioning, but when it's cold, you just don't want to go outside because it's cold.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I think you're going to say heat.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Even though you grew up in the snow. Jesse, don't change --

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: -- I like I'm looking at the pine trees in the snow. I just couldn't do it forever. It's like a weekend thing.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Yes. Snow once in a while or -- over 100 degrees, though. Jesse? Over a --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: What kind of heat is it, then?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Yes. I'm going to take the under.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: We're going to end up there anyway at some point. It'll be called Florida, though,.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: That's right. That's a moist heat.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: That's a humid head. All right. Juan, do you like heat?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I like heat because I don't like cold weather. But I do think that it's pretty special to have snow. I guess, you know, because I've been indoctrinated by American visions of what a perfect Christmas is, and a perfect Christmas is snowy.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I think if Kennedy were here, she would say snow.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Pretty sure. Right. She wants to ski and snowboard and all that fun stuff. All right. Another question from Karen D. What was the one chore you disliked doing growing up? Jesse, did you have a chore?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I had to do the baseboards. You know, the baseboards --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- at the bottom of the wall near the floor. And so my mom would say, "Get a bucket, fill it with hot water, puts some Mr. Clean in there and then take a wet rag and dip it in there and then just scrub the baseboards all over the house. You know, that gave me back problems I think. Bending over so much as a young child I think it was abusive.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: You know, your mom would say she has back problems for having a kid, right?

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: That's worse. I bartered with my brother not to have to clean the bathrooms.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: So we would trade chores. So I would vacuum and do like the garage --

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: -- or the kitchen, empty the dishwasher but he would cover the bathrooms.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: You can make like the nice the like the lines in the carpet.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Yes. Oh really want to tell women all across --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Compared to what I did the baseboards. That's grueling. Vacuuming, you stand up and go [makes sounds]

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Not if you get under the couch.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Unless you're like Greg and you have a Roomba.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Juan, did you have a chore you didn't like?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You know, I didn't like taking out the trash. And the reason is that if you live in an apartment building, you have to go out in the hallway, and then down to the garbage chute. Right? And sometimes there'd be bad guys there, Dana.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I know. I know well. Greg, what about you?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Trying to think if I really had any chores?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I mean, no but I got paid for what I did. Is that a chore?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I did a lot of fun stuff. Usually wore cutoff jeans, shirtless.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Did you get paid for that?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: The neighbors threw money at me.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I tell you, the worst chore for us was changing the cat litter box.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: That is not a fun chore.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Oh I can do another one. We had to go out -- we had pigeons for the Labradors that we would train.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: And we had to feed the pigeons, and it was really cold.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Just like pigeon food. I don't know. Bird feed.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: We had to go out and feed them.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Wait a minute. Wait a minute.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: In like 20 degree weather. It was terrible.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: There's an area there's an unbelievable story hidden in there.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to tell the rats because PETA will be after me.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's why you had the pigeons.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: All right. Greg, if you could teach one college class, what would it be?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Oh, it would have -- the media and why they lie to you. That's what it would be.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I think he would be at liberty.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I would teach ambush journalism 101. It was really the only thing I was ever good at --

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- and I've done it more than anybody.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: And I know how to do it.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I would teach a history class that's pro-America because it doesn't really happen.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That's so not a Fox News answer.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Whatever. I don't care. That's what I would do.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I guess it's great ideas. I would be interested -- you know, I was a philosophy major. I think you were a philosophy major.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Yeah, and then I changed the history.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I was like, "Uh, I'm changing majors."

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Actually, now at this point in life I wish that I had done history or political science, but I did philosophy, and I am still interested in great ideas. Like how do you live a good life? That would be, you know.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I would teach a class on, especially for women, in finding their strong voice because it helps in all sorts aspects of your life, career, being able to actually present in a way that will help make sure that you have opportunities for promotion and things like that.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: In the spirit, in the Christmas spirit, let me tell you, Greg, and I think I agree that they should teach you how to balance a checkbook, how to invest in stock --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I think the parents should do that.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, somebody should do it. Right?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Like you shouldn't have to pay tuition to have somebody tell you how to balance your checkbook.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Well no, there are lots of life skills that I just didn't. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: We used to have home ec, and then they took it away.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I loved home ec. I made, a cupcake pillow. Okay. Greg.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: This is from Henry S. What is your favorite time of the day and why?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Oh, geez my favorite time of the day is when you wake up and you realize you have like two more hours of sleep. That's my favorite. So like --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Oh, and you can go right back to sleep?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I'm talking at like 10:00 a.m. like when you wake up at 10, and, "It's only 10:00 a.m." and then I just go back to sleep.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: [LAUGHS] "I don't have to be at work until 5."

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes. The best time is when you wake up and you still have time to sleep. Everybody does that. They always wake, and they're so excited when they look at it and it says --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You know what, you what this means?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Because I can tell you from personal experience --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Juan, your favorite time of day?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Well, I would guess that it's, you know, like work is done, and I don't have any writing or something to do. And I just like, "Hey, this is my time. I can have a beer. I can sit and watch The Five on rerun or baseball. Or I can call up Jesse and complain."

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: You watch The Five on rerun?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I have, but I don't. I don't make it -- but I do watch -- you know what I watch?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You know what I watch? I watch I watch Family Feud.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Favorite time of day I think dawn, because no one else is awake. You can go get stuff done. You're by yourself. You have some peace and quiet. Get your coffee, go workout, read a little bit.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Get a lot of stuff done.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: And then you have the rest of the day.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: As long as you get plenty of sleep.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I'm a morning person like Katie, but I also like 8:59. You want to know why? Hannity is almost on, and it's just that anticipation of the monologue. It's just so good.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I like dusk or the golden hour.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Not when I'm working, but like on a Saturday and Sunday. That's definitely my favorite time. All right. Who would be the first person we'd contact in an emergency? Here at Fox News, the answer when The Five's Christmas fan mail special continues.

utterances.speaker: Mike Emmanuel
utterances.utterance: Merry Christmas from Fox News in Washington, I'm Mike Emmanuel. The Five continues in a moment, but first, this Special Report news break. Breaking tonight from the Middle East, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reportedly rushed to a bomb shelter. A rocket was fired in the direction of where he was holding a campaign event. President Trump and first lady Melania are wishing each and every American a Merry Christmas. They're also sending their holiday greetings to our troops stationed around the globe. And in a written statement, the president's calling for deeper understanding and respect as we head into a new year. Meanwhile, the Cal in California, the Democratic governor, just paroled an illegal immigrant from Cambodia who had spent 22 years in prison for killing a rival gang member. He was then immediately turned over to federal ICE authorities for possible deportation. I'll be back at 6:00 p.m. Eastern time for a live special report now back to The Five.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Merry Christmas, everybody. Welcome back to The Five's Christmas special. We're going to answer some more of your questions from social media. All right. Number one, Facebook question, Kimberly D. -- if you had an emergency, who at Fox News would be the first person you called for help? Juan?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Well, it would have to do with the nature of the emergency. Now if someone's trying to kill me, I guess I'd call security.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You couldn't call me cause I'd be chasing you with an ax.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. Can't be you. That's not fair. You'd have to protect me, Greg.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Like who is your emergency contact?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Yes. Like if there is a problem.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I would guess it's Megan Albano who is the boss of this show, right?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Okay. Call the boss. Okay. Not the person I would call but Dana.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I'm going to go with Sean Hannity.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Because he always takes your calls. He has the resources to help you. And he will make you feel better about whatever has happened.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Sean does have a very tender, loving touch. I would definitely call Dr. Marc Siegel. because that, you know, speaks to the emergency that I would be having.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Because I think I must call Dr. Marc Siegel at least three times a day, 99 percent for no reason at all. So I'm going to have to go with Kilmeade because Kilmeade is always here.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: And whenever you see Kilmeade, do you notice he always has a backpack?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: He's like that oldest guy with a backpack, he's always walking around with -- so I figure it must got stuff in the backpack --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- in case I'm trapped in an elevator. Actually, you know what?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Rick Leventhal. You think about Rick Le -- he would -- Rick Leventhal is our, is our --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: If you're stuck in an elevator, remember when he was stuck in the elevator, when Leventhal was stuck in an elevator? Do you remember that?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Oh, look it up. Google it. But he'd crawl through the little slot and get you out of there.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Leventhal, Kilmeade, Dr. Siegel -- that's your super friends. And Hannity.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Wait a minute, wait a minute. I thought you'd call Tyrus.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That's true. But Tyrus lives, you know, he doesn't live nearby.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I would call Johnny Joey Jones because he's a Marine. He would know what to do. And he knows all the other Marines so they could come with medical supplies and guns and all helicopters. Everything we would need [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: That's true. And he needs it. All right, Instagram question from Gunner Baker. "If you could only eat at one restaurant for the rest of your life -- no pressure -- where would it be and why?" Greg?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I can't say because it would put the poor place out of business. There's a Chinese restaurant that has my favorite ribs, which I order maybe three times a week when I'm on my way home. It's downtown.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Every night, ribs for the rest of your life.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes, but then put it with Chinese food. They have like 300 other options and also they got fried chicken.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: That's true. Such a healthy guy, Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I think if you were Jewish, that'd be your Christmas dinner.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: That's it. That's where everybody is eating the night. Right? All right, Juan?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Well, it depends. If I was in Washington, it'd be Ocean Air, which is a great seafood restaurant. But if I'm in New York, I go across the street to Oceana, which is another great seafood -- because we have a wide variety of seafood.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Wow, you're getting paid well, Juan.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I know some of these people don't eat seafood. I don't understand. I love seafood.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: You should hear what he says about the ocean.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Didn't you hear what Dana said?.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I know, both of them have issues.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I would do that place called Acqua Al 2.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Because it's an Italian place, but they have everything, salad, steak and the best pasta in town.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Not only that, they have all the Washington Nationals eat there.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: That's true. You can hang out and party.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Is your answer Del Frisco's because my answer is Del Frisco's.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: My answer is not Del Frisco's because obviously you're doing very well, and your wallet must be very fat if you're eating at Del Frisco's.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Well, there's other options. You don't have to get the crab.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: No, I want to mention something that's not as famous, but Greg knows this restaurant. It's the West Side Steakhouse.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: It's on 10th Avenue in New York. And a great owner and lovely -- his lovely wife there. And while they have a wonderful menu, they'll make you anything you want.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Wait. People are going to now go there and start ordering things that they don't have. They go "Dana Perino says, I want lobster thermidors." [LAUGHTER] [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I was just about to say that.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Well, they could probably make it.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I don't think they have lobster there, but who knows? Maybe they do.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Okay, well, I'm going to go there and test that theory, Dana. You guys better be ready for us. All right. Instagram question from Le Groan Ellen [spelled phonetically], "what do you miss most about your hometown?" I miss the cheese sticks in Philly. Just going out, getting a cheese steak anytime. No car.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: -- in your cheese steak, no calories.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Those are for tourists. No one really goes there.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Wait, where did you go then?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Local places like Chubby's, Dalessandro's, you know.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: What do I -- I miss the [unintelligible] mall in the old days, like the old-fashioned shopping malls where you had like the Chess King, Wet Seal, Spencer's. It was just the tackiest place in the world. But that's where everybody went when you were from like 7 years old to 17 was the mall. Now we have it on. Now we have Amazon.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Is that where you wore those short jean shorts with the tank top?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes. That's where I'd get my -- never mind. I almost said -- it was going to be edited out anyway, so why say it?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It was just a terrible clothing store.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Merry Go Round. Remember Merry Go Round?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I've never heard of any of these places.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Boutique Sophisticate? You probably shopped there.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: No, I was a Baby GAP.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Because you didn't really have a town.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You should go to Mountain View, California.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: We're going to edit that out. What about you? What do you miss?

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I miss mountains and open space.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Eighty miles an hour speed limit.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: In California -- I mean, in New York, the average, what is it three miles an hour in Manhattan? That's the average.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Did we do you, Juan? What do you [unintelligible]?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: No, I mean, look, it doesn't fit, but I mean, it's the truth. I was like a street urchin in Brooklyn, New York. So playing basketball on the streets, stickball on the street, being on the streets to the point where people are worried about what's going on with this guy. I liked it actually; I had a great time.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: You just don't miss taking out the garbage.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: That's true. Okay Facebook question from Paul A. -- how do you deal with a bad hair day? I don't know. I've never had one. Can't answer that question. Katie, what do you do?

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I just put my hair in a ponytail.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I go to makeup. We have professionals here.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Greg, what do you throw a hat on?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I just adjust it. I just adjust or I get another one.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Okay. Do we have time for one more?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: They've been teasing for the last two minutes.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Ponytail. Come on, we got to go. Greg, we got to go. What is the most opinion that we have? Find out when we return.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Now, that's a holiday song. Fifty third and third by the Ramones. Look it up, has an interesting meaning. All right. First question, Instagram from Joni, I guess. What's your most unpopular opinion? I think donuts are overrated. That's not an unpopular opinion. That's just stupid.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: No. Donuts are the greatest thing ever made. It just they give you a little heartburn because they're so filled with so much sugar. Dana, what's your most unpopular opinion?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: So, I think it's that I still am on the fence and against the legalization of marijuana.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That's all right. That's not so --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah. But that's all right. That upsets Jesse because he's high right now.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Oh, man. I was just going back in time for a second, man. This morning was so cool. All the lights on the trees.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: All right. What's your unpopular opinion?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: You know, usually people don't disagree with me. I don't have a lot of unpopular opinions.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I know my unpopular opinion at home is that Trump is a great president.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: That is a very unpopular opinion in the Watters household.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That is true. That is true. Juan, unpopular opinion.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Are you kidding? I work here. Come on. Be for real.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I would say my unpopular opinion is that trophy hunting is actually beneficial in a lot of places in Africa.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Mine is obvious. I don't like this time of the season. Don't like it.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: But wait. Can we go back.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Because it sustains a lot of the local populations with not only food, but jobs, and an economy, and I could go on and on. But --

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: -- if you ask the people who live there, who are hunting guides and that kind of thing, they will say, "We actually like this kind of thing and Westerner should probably stay out of it.”

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Well, I've got to read up on that.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Wait, wait, wait. We can have a new segment.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: They are yummy. I bet people are eating them today.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes. In your dream house, what is one weird room -- this is a scary question -- feature you would include in your dream house? What would it be? Get it over with, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: How did you know I was chomping at the bit?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: We have a safe word. No. I want like a spa in the house with steam or a sauna and then an ice plunge --

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I would never do an ice plunge.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: All right. Dream house. One weird rumor feature.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: One weird room or feature? I like the movie theater in the house. I think that's really cool.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That's not weird though, that's -- you'll be able to do that in a few years.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Keep your head down, and keep working hard, Katie.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Don't talk about we just talked about.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I would like a room that was dedicated to all the Pilates apparati [sic]--

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That sounds like the name of a dancer I knew.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: No. You -- okay. When I was young, I wanted my own fast food restaurant in my house.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That was my rich fantasy. There was going to be Jack in the Box, which could be the first floor. You can come home and order anything off the menu.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: But then you realize as you get older that you can't do that because you be dead by thirty.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: So rich people, though, I noticed oftentimes they have gyms in their house.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Like they have a basketball court right there.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I'm not that rich. [LAUGHS] I don't know.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Juan, I think you can afford a court. Come on.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Juan, you've been on The Five for 15 years.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: And that's even 7 years longer than The Five has been around. I want a moat, but I want an indoor moat. Like I want to be able to swim around my house. So it's about this wide --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I want a lazy river in my house. So I can just swim -- now, I live in an apartment, but it would be great just to be swimming around the house. Like, oh --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- have little cocktails, have a bar, a swim up bar like they --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Just swim around. I would never leave home.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: There is a house like this. You know that?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: In Wisconsin with the -- the river goes through the house.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: It's called Neverland, Juan. We don't like to talk about it.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: All right. They're yelling at me. What's the last song played on your phone? The answer when we come back.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Greg hates that song as well. We are answering your questions on our Christmas fan mail special. So this question comes from Instagram from John Gone 24 [spelled phonetically] If you looked up your iPod to the studio speakers right now, what song is playing? Greg, A, do you have an iPod, and, B, which song was playing? [LAUGHS]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I do have an iPod. I'm the only one -- probably only person left on the planet that has an actual iPod.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I like it separate from my phone. Moon Diagrams, some strange band. Pretty good.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: One album. It's called Moon Diagrams. That was what I had listened to on the plane.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I'm going to just hit play.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Yeah, right. I don't believe you.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: That was the last thing I played. String Q.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I just -- it was paused. I just hit play. It was the last thing on my phone.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Did you play this to have people think that you actually listen to this kind of music?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I was a flutist for 15 years.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: All right. There you go. Dana?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Well, I just looked it up, and it's a 90s country remix by Walker Hayes.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Played Jesus I Never Forget by Sam Cooke.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Mine was the Chain by Fleetwood Mac.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: How's that go again? Never break the --

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to sing again, I already sang Feliz Navidad.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to sing another song.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I'm drawing the line, but only Spanish songs are what I sing because we sound a little better. You don't have to worry about your accent. All right. Next question. What photo is on your cell phone background? Jesse?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I have a beach background, some waves.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: He's got the one that comes with the phone.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Is that the default? I have the default.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I have a picture of Jasper and me at a party in the summer.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I don't even know you could do it. That's good news to me.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: You can do a wallpaper or a photo. Juan?

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I think it's wallpaper. I don't think I have one.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: So is this a woman thing, Dana?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Obviously, it's people who know how to use their iPhones.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, I don't want Jaspar on my phone.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Both pictures of my husband and my dog.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That's what it'll be. You won't able to get it off.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: You should choose one. It's kind of fun. I'm not going to choose one for you.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: That would be good. Okay. Question number three from Facebook from Olivia P. What is one physical item you think everyone should have? This is hard.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I think everybody should have a really nice leather good.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Like a whether it be a purse, a duffel bag, like something, like a nice leather goods. I think that's very good thing to have.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I mean, you try buy it --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- very broad with your "leather goods." That could be anything, chaps.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Everyone needs a good pair of chaps.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I think everyone needs a nice pair of shoes. Men especially because women, the first thing they look at is your feet, and they judge you on the shoes you wear.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I've read this thousands of times.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You are like -- you're a font of conventional wisdom. I know what I've heard it from you I've already heard it.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Juan, what do you think I should have? One item.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: I didn't know. I was thinking like a nice suit in case you got to go someplace. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: I would say a life straw.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: It filters out your water in case the water's bad.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: You can buy them on Amazon.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: It's not a skill, it's an item.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Well, true, but it's a skill to buy one. Yeah. Life straw. Let's see. Number four, Instagram question from Barnes Gibby [spelled phonetically], what is your least favorite mode of transportation? Mine's a bus because there's no bathroom on a bus.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Not what I heard, Greg. [LAUGHS] I've been carrying you the whole show. I don't like rickshaws. They rip you off, and they take forever.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I'm going to say a slow train.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I hate a slow train. I like a fast train.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: No, I don't like the ground moving underneath me. It makes me sick.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: No, it's not cool. Not cool.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: You don't like a cruise ship to take you?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: No, I'll get sea sickness in the slightest -- well, of course I would. [LAUGHS]

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: All right. One more question. Right? One more? Okay. Instagram question from Cesar [spelled phonetically] When was the last time you got to tell someone I told you so?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: I mean I can't wait to talk about this FISA stuff with Juan.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: That's the way I felt you know, but, you know, there's so much of this, but I don't want to be political. So I'm going leave that alone for the moment. But told you so would be like, you know, out with my kids, and they're eating something, and I said, "I told you that was nasty." You know, "Don't eat it.”

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I never say because I can never remember what I've said.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: Okay. All right. One more question from one more viewer up next.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: This show has been an instant Christmas classic, so welcome back. It's time for one last Christmas question. What do you eat for Christmas dinner, Katie?

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Moose is the plural of mice.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: No, it's not. We learned this. No, it's not.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Ribeye or eye of the round.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: You do not cook it. All right. Your mom?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Whatever is available because I usually am invited to go somewhere. [LAUGHS] But ham, usually, ham I think. Maybe steak. Oh, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Also, really, truly is just I'm really there for the wine.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Which is great by that time.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I wonder do they sell those Honey baked ham stores?

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: Yes. I just ordered one for as a gift for somebody that will arrive --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I would probably do the -- I always have steak.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Because I generally I'm eating at a restaurant at Christmas time, and it's the best way to do Christmas because, no, you don't have to do dishes.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You have the people around you--

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, of course. Oh, not this again.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: So I like ham, but I don't eat that much meat. But at Christmas time, there are two types of hams. There's a honey-baked ham that you talked about, but there's also a salted ham.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Oh, I don't like the salted ham.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's different. But, you know --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: My brother-in-law is like a doctor and you watch him cut it.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That would be a great business card. "Like a doctor."

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: It is. But to watch him carve up that ham, you know, it's a big deal. Anyway, we had time for one last question. And of course, I mean, this may be the question of questions.

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: The hardest person in your life to buy a gift for.

utterances.speaker: Katie Pavlich
utterances.utterance: He has everything. He has everything.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Sophia, my one daughter. Yeah, she's impossible.

utterances.speaker: Jesse Watters
utterances.utterance: Impossible. Well, the other Ellie is easy because it's so easy. But Sofia is impossible.

utterances.speaker: Dana Perino
utterances.utterance: I'm going to say my dad, too.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Clooney. Every time -- every year, I get something and then it's like he's super polite about it, but I know --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: He has it. So then it's like then I -- and I never see him use it, so --

utterances.speaker: Juan Williams
utterances.utterance: All right. Thanks for spending some of your holiday with us. We're going to see you back here tomorrow. Merry Christmas to everyone and to all, good night.
